descendants.content:
@Jgmeadows 50% of voters don't think climate change is real and push back against even minimal efforts to address it.

So no, I can't imagine a mainstream politician campaigning by telling people they are going to do more than what is already being resisted.

account.note:
A privileged Canadian trying to make sense of the incomprehensible.

Curious about the weird borderlands between the certain and the impossible.

I used to make software. Now I ponder human nature, its contradictions, absurdities, and tragedies. And wonder if we can make it better.

What is the nature of storytelling?

Dogmatism, fanaticism, abuse get blocked.

descendants.content: @Tom @Jgmeadows Fee and Dividend in Ontario is first and foremost a climate policy; albeit an abysmally marketed climate policy. It can also be viewed in a different lens as a “take revenue from oil companies and redistribute it to consumers”. If you want to know who is really behind the “axe the tax” movement look no further than who gets the revenue back. Ask anyone in Ontario if they saw the revenue from Doug Ford’s sales cut tax on gas 2022July1.

account.note: Retired engineer. Interested in clean hydrogen as energy currency, economic systems where endless growth isn’t a built in requirement, and areas of science, archeology and technology where new discoveries and new data are contradicting established narratives.

descendants.content: @Jgmeadows I imagine this all of the time, and if any one of them actually had the guts to do it, they’d get my vote. I think the Greens come the closest, but they still won’t actually come right out with the brutal honesty needed. As for the rest of them, nope. They want us all to believe that we can comfortably eat our cake while the guillotine is falling on our heads.

descendants.content: @Jgmeadows so much easier to come out with crocodile tears after disasters and pretend like your policies did nothing to lead to said disasters.

descendants.content:

That's another use of non-electoral political organizations.

Party meetings promote partisanship, and since their primary goal is winning, they suppress adult debate.

Of course, only a few will join, but they can engage the rest of the community.

descendants.content: @Jgmeadows It’s a weakness of democratic systems and human psychology. Any politician running on a platform like that would be unelectable. Any politician in office who instituted the necessary reforms would be booted out and replaced by the guy selling comforting lies. I fear that most people will have to feel a lot more pain before they are willing to do what is required.
